messageBody:
Step 1: Try to test the *feature* and not just each method. That might
solve your problem, by giving you a natural name for those tests.

As an example, when I test that my data model class handles a data store
with no widgets in it, I generally write a test like:

testNoWidgets() {
MockDataModel model = new MockDataModel(); // MockDataModel extends
DataModel
model.ensureNoWidgets(); // special method on mock data model to let
me "sneak in" and change things.

// Test public interface of DataModel when there are no widgets.
assertEquals(0, model.countWidgets());

assertTrue(model.collectAllWidgets().isEmpty());

assertTrue(model.collectAllWidgets(new WidgetFilter() {
public void accept(Widget each) {
// Accept all widgets.
}
}).isEmpty());

model.eachWidget(new WidgetBlock() {
public void execute(Widget each) {
fail("How did I get here?!");
}
});
...
}

Notice that I create a scenario, then test each method under that scenario.
This is an inverse view from writing a separate test for each method, then
varying the scenarios.

Step 2: If Step 1 fails because you can't figure out a good way to do it,
then there is no "rule". I would suggest naming the test methods by what
the method under test *does* and not its signature.

testEngineDigestReturnsEmptyBuffer() {
// simulate/set up empty buffer...
assertNotNull("engineDigest() returned null?!", myObject.engineDigest
());
assertEquals(0, myObject.engineDigest().length);
}
...
testEngineDigestAcceptsEmptyBuffer() {
assertEquals(0, engineDigest(new byte[0], 0, 0));
}

You would have similar tests for buffers of different sizes, contents, or
whatever variables might change, given the feature you're trying to
implement.

Good luck,

Subject: [junit] names for overloading methods




Hello,

is there a rule how I should choose the names for overloading
methods like these in my test class:

protected byte[] engineDigest(){}
protected int engineDigest(byte[] buf, int offset, int len){}


1. should I use one test method like:

public void testEngineDigest(){}



2. Or should I use two names with diffrent extensions like these:

public void testEngineDigest_byte(){}
public void testEngineDigest_byte_array(){}
